title: I owe 30,000 in debt. Should I file bankruptcy. I would like to keep my house and car
question: Credit and unsecured loans
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy means test,Credit score,Credit,Debt,Debt settlement,Secured debt,Unsecured debt,Bankruptcy and debt
answers:
I would say you Should file bankruptcy if you cannot pay your debts as they come due. Whether filing will result in a loss of assets, whether your income is low enough so that filing is not an abuse of the bankruptcy process, whether the debts are dischargeable, what type of bankruptcy you should file and many other questions must be answered first before you make that decision.

This forum is great for simple questions. Whether you should file bankruptcy is not a simple question. Find an experienced bankruptcy attorney and set up an appointment. Many attorneys will do this by phone. That's really the only way to get the answers you need.
Usually, depending on the numbers you can keep your house and car, depending on the amount of equity in each. You need to consult a competent bankruptcy attorney.

Click on the Find a Lawyer tab on Avvo to find bankruptcy attorneys in your area. Most offer a free initial consult. The attorney can review your options with you to come up with the best option for you. One piece of advice: don't fall for these debt consolidation offers. Most of them are scams.

I fully agree with Attorney Ruthven. Before filing for bankruptcy, you need to speak with a competent attorney who can go over all of the facts and circumstances of your debt as well as the equity in your home and automobile.

Lots of factors go into such a decision, especially including how much equity you have in your house. Do yourself a big favor and consult with an experienced bankruptcy attorney about your entire financial situation.

A number of factors must be considered when determining if a bankruptcy is the right thing to do and if so, which chapter the debtor should file under. Some of those factors are:

1) total amount of unsecured debt such as credit card debt, medical bills, personal loans, old utility bills, etc.;
2) total amount of secured debt such as auto loans, house mortgages and loans that have other items as collateral;
3) for loans made to purchase autos and other personal property in which the collateral are the purchased items, did you purchase the auto more or less than 2.5 years ago or did your purchase other personal property more or less than one year ago;
4) what is the interest rate on you secured loans and would a reduction to around 5.0% help you significantly;
5) for the tax debt is the debt dischargeable in a chapter 7 or chapter 13, and if not, would discharging the penalties in a chapter 13 and stopping the interest from running on the tax be a significant savings;
6) your projected income and expenses and you means test income and expenses, which considers your average income over the past 6 months;
7) what assets do you own that are exempt and what assets that you own that are not exempt;
8) is your income subject to being garnished by a judgment creditor if you decide not to file; and
9) your current credit score, which if it is already extremely low now, your score could be helped by filing and doing the right things to rebuild your credit after entry of the discharge order in your case.

You need to take advantage of a free initial consultation with an experienced bankruptcy attorney that handles chapter 7 and chapter 13 cases even if you think you need to file under chapter 7. Become educated on all the issues involved and related to your current economic situation, find out the advantages and disadvantages for filing under each chapter and use an attorney that can help you make the right decision for you. Most bankruptcy attorneys will meet with you at no charge for the initial appointment. You can use the Avvo "Find a Lawyer" link at the top of this page to search for an attorney.
